children.text: Select all statements that correctly describe capabilities or objectives of SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad from the context.
Prompt (excerpt): Prompt excerpt unavailable.

The context outlines how SAP AI Core operationalizes AI (training, batch inference, serving via REST) with enterprise features (GPU scaling, multi-tenancy, pay-for-usage) and how SAP AI Launchpad centralizes lifecycle management, connects to AI API-enabled services, and enables monitoring and productization. It also notes GitOps onboarding and initial setup prerequisites without detailing exact answers.

Prompt (excerpt): "After completing this lesson, you will be able to: Illustrate the process involved in working with SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad; Connect SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad to user's docker and GitHub repositories."
SAP AI Core provides orchestration for training and batch inference and can serve model inference via a REST endpoint.
The context explicitly states orchestration of trainings and batch inference, and model serving (inference) via REST.
SAP AI Launchpad centralizes AI lifecycle management by connecting to AI API-enabled services with uniform training, deployment, and model status.
The context describes Launchpad as centralizing lifecycle management with uniform status/training/deployment across services.
Using SAP AI Core requires paying a fixed monthly fee for compute regardless of usage to ensure capacity.
The text notes pay-for-used resources and on-demand scaling, not fixed fees regardless of usage.
Multi-tenancy in SAP AI Core ensures tenant isolation so that each customer’s data and AI assets are separated.
The context states tenant isolation with multi-tenancy and describes separate resource groups per subtenant.
SAP AI Launchpad replaces SAP AI Core for running trainings and serving inference, making AI Core optional.
The text presents Launchpad as a management/monitoring web application that can trigger jobs and deploy models, not a replacement for AI Core’s runtime orchestration/serving.
Look for phrases about orchestration, serving, and REST endpoints for AI Core.
Identify Launchpad’s role in centralizing lifecycle and providing uniform status across services.
Core = do (train/serve); Launchpad = manage (centralize/monitor).

A, B, and D align with the described capabilities: AI Core orchestrates and serves; Launchpad centralizes lifecycle; multi-tenancy isolates tenants. C contradicts pay-for-use. E miscasts Launchpad as a replacement rather than a management layer.
Cite the lines that mention pay-for-use and multi-tenancy to justify selections.
A team trains a model on AI Core with GPU, serves it via REST, and uses Launchpad to monitor status and trigger retraining.
Which statement best distinguishes SAP AI Core from SAP AI Launchpad based on their primary roles?

The materials describe SAP AI Core as providing orchestration, serving, and delivery capabilities for AI workflows, while SAP AI Launchpad focuses on managing and monitoring AI models and lifecycles across services on SAP BTP.

Prompt (excerpt): “Illustrate the process involved in working with SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad … The main capabilities that SAP AI Core provides are the orchestration of AI workflows … SAP AI Launchpad is a service … to transparently manage AI models across the enterprise.”
AI Core operationalizes and serves models and workflows; Launchpad centralizes lifecycle management and monitoring across AI services.
Matches the text: AI Core handles orchestration, training, batch/online inference, and delivery; Launchpad manages and monitors models and lifecycles across AI API-enabled services.
AI Core is primarily a web UI for monitoring multiple clouds; Launchpad performs model training and serving.
Reversed: Launchpad provides management/monitoring; Core provides training/serving orchestration.
Both AI Core and Launchpad are limited to CPU-only workloads to control costs.
Contradicted: the text notes GPU support for performance in AI Core.
AI Core exclusively manages model KPIs, while Launchpad handles GitOps onboarding.
Incorrect mapping: Launchpad covers lifecycle transparency and KPIs; GitOps onboarding is tied to AI Core configuration.
Launchpad provides tenant isolation and resource-based billing; AI Core offers only a read-only registry of models.
Tenant isolation and pay-for-use are described for AI Core; Launchpad is for centralized management, not billing isolation.
Identify which service runs workflows (training/inference) vs. which one manages lifecycles and monitoring.
Look for references to GPU support, orchestration, and serving to spot AI Core.
Core = run and serve; Launchpad = manage and monitor.

The text positions AI Core as the execution/orchestration layer (training, batch/online inference, deployment, serving) with enterprise features, while Launchpad centralizes lifecycle management, transparency, and monitoring across AI API-enabled services.
List two execution-focused capabilities of AI Core and two management-focused capabilities of Launchpad from the text.
Example: Use AI Core to deploy a model to a REST endpoint; use Launchpad to track its status and retraining cycles.
Which statement best captures how SAP AI Launchpad complements SAP AI Core according to the lesson?
The lesson introduces SAP AI Core for orchestrating and serving AI workflows and SAP AI Launchpad for centralized lifecycle management and monitoring across AI services.
Prompt (excerpt): “Illustrate the process involved in working with SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad … Centralize AI lifecycle management … Monitor and continuously improve model performance.”
AI Launchpad centralizes lifecycle management and monitoring across AI API-enabled services, complementing AI Core’s orchestration and serving.
Launchpad provides centralized management and monitoring, while AI Core handles orchestration (training, batch inference) and serving.
AI Launchpad replaces AI Core’s orchestration features by executing model training itself.
The text assigns orchestration (including training) to AI Core, not Launchpad.
AI Launchpad is limited to a single runtime and does not connect to AI API-enabled services.
The text says Launchpad connects to AI API-enabled services and supports uniform management regardless of underlying technology.
AI Launchpad primarily provides GPU acceleration to reduce training time.
GPU acceleration and cost-performance balance are described under AI Core’s value, not Launchpad’s.
AI Launchpad stores customers’ training data to ensure tenant isolation across resource groups.
Tenant isolation via separate resource groups is attributed to AI Core; Launchpad focuses on management and monitoring.
Identify which service handles orchestration and serving versus management and monitoring.
Look for mentions of AI API-enabled services and uniform lifecycle management.
Core = do (orchestrate/serve); Launchpad = oversee (manage/monitor).
The lesson positions AI Core for executing AI workflows and serving, while AI Launchpad provides centralized lifecycle management and monitoring across connected AI services.
Describe one AI Core capability and one Launchpad capability that together support end-to-end operations.
A team trains and serves a model via AI Core and tracks deployments and retraining schedules via AI Launchpad.
The statement below is accurate according to the text.
Statement: SAP AI Core provides orchestration for model training and batch inference, and can serve model inference via a REST endpoint.

The context describes SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad roles, capabilities, and objectives, including lifecycle orchestration, serving predictions, and management across the enterprise, without indicating any evaluative judgment.
True
False
Check what the text lists as the main capabilities of SAP AI Core.
Look for mentions of training, batch inference, and how predictions are exposed.
Core = orchestrate and serve; Launchpad = manage and monitor.
The text states SAP AI Core orchestrates AI workflows (model trainings and batch inference) and serves model inference so models can make predictions via a REST endpoint.
Summarize one capability of AI Launchpad that complements AI Core.
A team uses AI Core to train and deploy a model; predictions are accessed through a REST endpoint, while Launchpad tracks deployment status.
Select all statements that are supported by the overview of SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad.

The context describes SAP AI Core as an orchestration and serving service with enterprise-grade operations, and SAP AI Launchpad as a centralized management web app connecting to AI API-enabled services and other platforms.

Prompt (excerpt): “Illustrate the process involved in working with SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad … connect SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad to user's docker and GitHub repositories … Centralize AI lifecycle management … orchestrate trainings, batch inference, and serving.”
SAP AI Core supports orchestration of model training and batch inference, and can serve models for prediction via a REST endpoint.
Explicitly stated: orchestration (training, batch inference) and serving (inference) via REST.
SAP AI Launchpad centralizes AI lifecycle management across AI API-enabled services and helps standardize training, deployment, and model status.
The text notes centralization, uniform statuses, and uniform training/deployment across connected services.
SAP AI Core mandates a single proprietary framework for all training jobs to ensure consistency.
Contradicted: it “retains openness to any AI framework.”
SAP AI Launchpad replaces the need for SAP AI Core by running training jobs natively without connecting to runtimes.
Unsupported: Launchpad is a web app for operating/monitoring and connecting to runtimes; it does not replace Core.
Using SAP AI Core always incurs fixed costs regardless of resource consumption to guarantee capacity.
Opposite of text: you pay for resources used, with on-demand scaling and GPU support.
Match each statement to explicit phrases like “orchestration,” “serving,” and “centralize lifecycle management.”
Eliminate claims that imply exclusivity or replacement when the text emphasizes openness and connectivity.
Check cost and scaling claims against the pay-for-use and GPU scaling notes.
Core = run and serve; Launchpad = manage and monitor.

A and B reflect the stated capabilities of Core (orchestration/serving) and Launchpad (centralized management). C conflicts with framework openness, D misstates Launchpad’s role, and E contradicts the pay-for-use model.
Identify the sentences describing Core’s orchestration and Launchpad’s centralization and relate them to A and B.
Example: Use AI Core to train and deploy a model with REST inference; use Launchpad to track deployment status and trigger retraining.
Which statement best characterizes SAP AI Core’s primary capabilities as described?

The lesson contrasts SAP AI Core (backend service capabilities) with SAP AI Launchpad (management and monitoring). Focus on what AI Core itself provides to productize and operate AI models without revealing the exact phrasing.

Prompt (excerpt): “The main capabilities that SAP AI Core provides are the orchestration of AI workflows, such as model trainings and batch inference, as well as serving model inference… The service offers continuous delivery capabilities, multi-tenancy, and pay-for-what-you-use scalability with GPU support.”
Orchestrating AI workflows (training and batch inference) and serving model inference, with enterprise features like continuous delivery, multi-tenancy, and scalable GPU-backed resources.
Directly reflects the described core functions and enterprise-grade features attributed to SAP AI Core.
Providing a web UI to centrally monitor AI models across multiple AI platforms and unify model status and deployments.
This describes SAP AI Launchpad, not AI Core.
Acting as a managed data warehouse to store training datasets and analytical reports.
The text mentions data sources like SAP HANA Cloud but does not position AI Core as a data warehouse.
Replacing Git-based version control by hosting model templates natively within the service.
The context points to using your own Git repository for templates via GitOps, not replacing Git.
Exclusively supporting a single AI framework to simplify deployment pipelines.
The text emphasizes openness to any AI framework, not exclusivity.
Differentiate backend orchestration/serving (AI Core) from UI-driven lifecycle management (Launchpad).
Look for mentions of training, batch inference, serving, and enterprise features like multi-tenancy and CD.
Core = engine (train, infer, serve); Launchpad = dashboard (monitor, manage).
AI Core handles workflow orchestration and serving with enterprise features (CD, multi-tenancy, GPU-backed scalability). Launchpad provides centralized monitoring and management across services.
Explain how GPU-backed scalability and pay-for-what-you-use relate to AI Core’s operational model.
A team triggers training and batch inference via AI Core and exposes a REST endpoint for predictions; they then view deployment status in AI Launchpad.
Which statement best characterizes how SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad complement each other in managing AI scenarios on SAP BTP?

The lesson introduces SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad, highlighting AI Core’s orchestration and serving of AI workflows, and Launchpad’s role in centralizing lifecycle management across AI API-enabled services.
Prompt (excerpt): "Illustrate the process involved in working with SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad" and "Connect SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad to user's docker and GitHub repositories."
AI Core runs and serves AI workflows (training, batch inference, model serving), while AI Launchpad centralizes lifecycle management and monitoring across AI API-enabled services.
Supported: AI Core orchestrates and serves models; Launchpad centralizes management, status, training/deployment, and monitoring.
AI Launchpad performs model training and inference, and AI Core only visualizes KPIs.
Contradicted: Training/inference orchestration is attributed to AI Core; Launchpad manages and monitors.
Both services are solely focused on GPU provisioning and cost metering without lifecycle features.
Incorrect: GPU/cost benefits are mentioned, but core value includes orchestration, serving, and lifecycle centralization.
AI Core is a web UI for multiple cloud AI platforms, and Launchpad is the backend that executes workflows.
Reversed: Launchpad is the web application for operating/monitoring; AI Core executes workflows.
AI Launchpad replaces GitOps, removing the need to connect repositories to AI Core.
Unsupported: The context mentions GitOps onboarding to AI Core; Launchpad does not replace it.
Distinguish execution/orchestration from management/monitoring.
Identify which service is the web application versus the backend service.
Core executes; Launchpad oversees.
AI Core provides orchestration and serving of AI workflows; AI Launchpad centralizes lifecycle management, status, training/deployment, and monitoring across AI API-enabled services.
Give an example of a task done in AI Core and how Launchpad would surface or manage it.
A team trains a model via AI Core and uses Launchpad to track status and trigger redeployment.
The statement below is accurate according to the text.
Statement: SAP AI Core provides orchestration for model training and batch inference, and also supports serving inference so models can make predictions.
The lesson outlines SAP AI Core capabilities for operationalizing AI (training, batch jobs, and serving) and SAP AI Launchpad for centralized lifecycle management and monitoring.
True
False
Recall which component handles orchestration of workflows like training and batch inference.
Check if the text mentions serving (inference) as part of SAP AI Core.
Core = do the work (train/batch/serve); Launchpad = manage and monitor.
According to the text, SAP AI Core orchestrates AI workflows such as model trainings and batch inference and serves model inference so models can make predictions.
Describe one lifecycle step handled by AI Launchpad that complements AI Core’s orchestration.
A team trains a model and deploys it for predictions via REST; these steps are orchestrated and served by SAP AI Core.
Select all statements that correctly describe resource groups, datasets, and configurations in SAP AI Core.

A resource group is a workspace where entities like configurations, executions, deployments, artifacts, and datasets are created or added. Datasets can be stored in a connected hyperscaler object store via an object store secret, and configurations define training inputs/outputs, pipeline containers, and required infrastructure (resource plans).
Prompt (excerpt): "Use ONLY the supplied context text; do not invent facts."
A resource group confines visibility so only allowed users can access its assets, such as a registered input dataset.
The text states a dataset’s resource group is only visible to those allowed to access that specific resource group.
Configurations specify training inputs/outputs, the pipeline containers, and infrastructure via resource plans.
The context notes configurations include information about input/output, pipeline containers, and required infrastructure (resource plans).
Connected hyperscaler object stores are primarily used for temporary logs, not datasets or models.
Contradicted: the connected storage is used for datasets, and produced models are stored there and registered.
Assets like Data, Training and Serving Templates are freely accessible across tenants.
Opposite of the note that such assets cannot be accessed by other tenants.
A single training pipeline cannot be reused with different datasets across runs to produce different models.
The note explicitly says different datasets can be injected into the same pipeline in different runs to yield different models.
Identify which statements align with visibility and segregation rules mentioned for resource groups and tenants.
Recall what configurations contain and how resource plans relate to infrastructure.
Check the role of the hyperscaler object store in storing datasets and models.
R-D-C: Resource group (restricts access), Datasets (in object store), Config (containers + resource plans).

A and B mirror the definitions: resource groups gate access to assets, and configurations define inputs/outputs, containers, and resource plans. C, D, and E contradict storage use, tenant isolation, and pipeline reuse described in the context.
Cite the specific lines that justify why A and B are correct.
Example: Register two dataset variants in the same resource group, then reuse the same configuration with a different resource plan to train on each variant.
Which statement best describes how datasets and models are handled in SAP AI Core when using resource groups and a connected object store?

A resource group is a workspace where configurations, executions, deployments, artifacts, and datasets can be managed. Access to a resource group scopes visibility of its assets. SAP AI Core connects to a hyperscaler object store via a secret to store datasets and models, and models produced by training are automatically registered and become ready for deployment.
Prompt (excerpt): Use ONLY the supplied context; provide five choices with one correct answer; keep context neutral and not revealing the answer.
Datasets are segregated by resource group, and trained models stored in the connected hyperscaler object store are automatically registered in SAP AI Core for deployment.
The context states datasets can be segregated within a resource group and that produced models are stored in the connected object store and automatically registered, ready for deployment.
Datasets are globally visible across all tenants, but models remain private to a single resource group.
The context notes segregation within a resource group and that assets like templates cannot be accessed by other tenants; it does not claim datasets are globally visible.
Models must be manually registered after training before they can be deployed.
The text explicitly says models produced and stored in the connected object store are automatically registered in SAP AI Core.
Object store credentials are optional because SAP AI Core stores datasets locally in the resource group.
The context describes connecting to a cloud object store via a secret; it is the storage used for datasets and models.
Resource groups contain only configurations and executions; datasets must be managed outside of them.
The context says users can create or add configurations, executions, deployments, artifacts, and notes that datasets can be segregated within a resource group.
Recall how visibility of assets changes when they are placed in a resource group.
Check what happens to a model after training when stored in the connected object store.
RG = scope; OS = store; train → store → auto-register → deploy.
Resource groups scope access to assets like datasets. With an object store connected, trained models are saved there and automatically registered in SAP AI Core, making them ready for deployment.
Explain why automatic registration matters for repeated training runs on different datasets.

A team runs the same training pipeline in two resource groups, each with its own dataset. Each run stores the model in the connected object store and the model is auto-registered for deployment per group.
In SAP AI Core, which statement best describes a resource group?

A resource group is associated with creating and isolating entities like configurations, executions, deployments, artifacts, and datasets within a workspace-like scope. Object store access is provided via a secret, and datasets/models can live in a connected hyperscaler object store. Different datasets can be injected into the same training pipeline across runs to yield different models.
Prompt (excerpt): Create EXACTLY 1 question of type: mcq. Use ONLY the supplied context text; do not invent facts.
A unique workspace-like scope where entities (e.g., configurations, executions, deployments, artifacts, datasets) are created and isolated for authorized users.
Matches the description: a resource group represents a unique workspace environment with segregated assets visible only to authorized users.
A global repository that lets all tenants access shared training templates and datasets by default.
The context notes assets cannot be accessed by other tenants; visibility is restricted.
An object store service that automatically grants SAP AI Core access without any secret configuration.
Access is managed via an object store secret; it is not automatic without configuration.
A pre-configured infrastructure bundle that specifies CPUs/GPUs used for training.
That describes resource plans, not resource groups.
A component that only holds models after training and is unrelated to configurations or executions.
Resource groups encompass configurations, executions, deployments, and artifacts, not only models.
Focus on isolation and which entities live inside the scope.
Differentiate resource groups from resource plans and object store configuration.
RG = Restricted Group: a workspace where only the right people see the right assets.
The text defines a resource group as a unique workspace environment that segregates entities and restricts visibility to authorized users, unlike shared/global repositories or infrastructure bundles.
Explain how dataset registration relates to resource groups and visibility.
Registering an input dataset for training requires a resource group; only permitted users of that group can consume it in runs.
The statement below is accurate according to the text.
Statement: Registering an input dataset in SAP AI Core presupposes the creation of a resource group, and that dataset is consumed by components within the same resource group.

Resource groups provide segregated workspaces for configurations, executions, deployments, and artifacts, with visibility restricted to permitted users. Object store secrets connect SAP AI Core to hyperscaler storage for datasets and models.
Prompt (excerpt): “Use ONLY the supplied context text; do not invent facts.”
True
False
Locate the sentence describing dataset registration requirements in AI Core.
Check how visibility and consumption are scoped to the resource group.
Think RG before data: Resource Group gates dataset registration and use.
The context states that registering a dataset in SAP AI Core assumes the creation of a resource group, and that the dataset is consumed by components belonging to the same resource group.
If this were false, what would need to change about how datasets are scoped across resource groups?
A team creates RG-A, registers a training dataset there, and only jobs in RG-A use it for model training.
Select all statements that are supported by the context about resource groups, datasets, object store integration, and configurations in SAP AI Core.

A resource group is a workspace for configurations, executions, deployments, and artifacts, with visibility limited to authorized users. Datasets can be segregated per resource group and injected into the same training pipeline across runs to produce different models. SAP AI Core connects to a hyperscaler object store via a secret to access datasets and store models; stored models are automatically registered and ready for deployment. Configurations define training inputs/outputs, pipeline containers, and infrastructure via resource plans (CPU/GPU variants).
Datasets can be registered within a resource group and used to run the same training pipeline on different dataset variants to yield distinct models.
The text states datasets are segregated by resource group and injected into the same pipeline in different runs, resulting in different models.
Connecting a hyperscaler object store via an object store secret provides SAP AI Core access to datasets and model storage.
The context explains that SAP AI Core connects to a cloud object store using a secret for dataset storage and that models are stored there.
Assets like Data, Training and Serving Templates are globally visible across tenants to simplify reuse.
The text explicitly notes such assets cannot be accessed by other tenants.
A configuration specifies training I/O, pipeline containers, and required infrastructure using resource plans that vary by CPUs/GPUs.
The description of configurations and resource plans (CPU/GPU differences) is given directly in the text.
When a model is produced, it must be manually registered in SAP AI Core before it is eligible for deployment.
The context states models stored in the connected object store are automatically registered and ready for deployment.
Identify which statements mention tenant visibility and asset segregation explicitly.
Recall what configurations include and how resource plans differ.
Note whether model registration after training is manual or automatic per the text.
R-G-O-C: Resource groups segregate, Git/object store provide access, Outputs auto-register, Configs choose compute.

A, B, and D align with the context on dataset segregation and reuse across runs, object store access via secrets, and configuration/resource plan details. C contradicts tenant isolation. E conflicts with automatic model registration.
Cite the sentences that describe automatic model registration and resource plan differences.
Example: Create two dataset variants in the same resource group, connect an object store via a secret, and run one configuration with a GPU resource plan to produce distinct, auto-registered models.
Which statement best describes a resource group in SAP AI Core?

In SAP AI Core, resource groups help organize and isolate work. They relate to creating configurations, executions, deployments, artifacts, and dataset registration, and tie into connected object storage for datasets and model outputs.
A resource group is a unique workspace where users create or add configurations, executions, deployments, and artifacts, with assets visible only to authorized users of that group.
Matches the description: a resource group is a unique workspace for configurations, executions, deployments, and artifacts, with access limited to allowed users.
A resource group is a global registry that lets all tenants access shared datasets and templates by default.
Contradicts the text; assets like datasets and templates are not accessible by other tenants, and visibility is limited to the group’s authorized users.
A resource group is an object store secret used to grant SAP AI Core access to hyperscaler storage.
Confuses concepts; object store secrets manage storage access, while resource groups are workspaces for AI Core assets and runs.
A resource group is a pre-configured infrastructure bundle (resource plan) that defines CPUs and GPUs for training.
Resource plans define compute; they are distinct from resource groups, which organize entities like configurations and executions.
A resource group is solely used to deploy models and cannot contain configurations or executions.
Incorrect; the text states resource groups can include configurations, executions, deployments, and artifacts.
Differentiate between organizational scope (resource group) and infrastructure or credential components.
Recall which entities can be created or added within the workspace environment.
RG = Resource Group as a wRappinG workspace: holds configs, runs, deploys, artifacts; not creds or compute plans.

The text defines a resource group as a unique workspace for configurations, executions, deployments, and artifacts with restricted visibility to authorized users. It is distinct from object store secrets (credentials) and resource plans (compute bundles).
Explain how dataset registration and model storage interact with a resource group and connected object store.
You register an input dataset and run multiple executions with different dataset variants; all are organized under the same resource group and stored in the connected object store.
In SAP AI Core, which statement best describes a resource group?

A resource group is used when organizing work in SAP AI Core alongside datasets, configurations, executions, deployments, and artifacts. Object store secrets connect to hyperscaler object storage, and datasets can be registered and consumed within the same workspace.
Prompt (excerpt): Provide an MCQ that uses only the supplied context and does not reveal the answer in the context.
It is a unique workspace where entities like configurations, executions, deployments, and artifacts are created or added.
Matches the description: a resource group represents a unique workspace environment hosting those entities.
It is the object store secret used to grant SAP AI Core access to hyperscaler storage.
The object store secret manages access; it is not the resource group.
It is a pre-configured infrastructure bundle (resource plan) defining CPUs and GPUs for training.
Resource plans are infrastructure bundles; they differ from resource groups.
It is a shared tenant-wide catalog that all tenants can access for datasets and models.
Assets like datasets are segregated; they are not accessible by other tenants.
It is the training pipeline definition that specifies containers and I/O for model training.
That describes a configuration/pipeline, not a resource group.
Differentiate between workspace scope (where things live) and access credentials (how storage is reached).
Resource plans and configurations are distinct from the workspace that contains them.
RG = Room (workspace) that holds configs, runs, deployments, and artifacts.

The context defines a resource group as a unique workspace environment containing configurations, executions, deployments, and artifacts. Other options describe object store secrets, resource plans, tenant-wide catalogs, or pipeline configurations.
List two entity types that reside in a resource group and explain how segregation affects visibility.
A team creates a resource group to register datasets and run executions; only members with access to that group can see those assets.
The statement below is accurate according to the text.
Statement: In SAP AI Core, registering an input dataset presupposes the existence of a resource group, and that dataset is visible only to users allowed to access that specific resource group.

Resource groups are workspace-scoped areas where entities like configurations, executions, deployments, artifacts, and datasets are managed. Access to a resource group determines who can see and consume its assets. Object store access is managed via a secret to a connected hyperscaler object store.
True
False
Recall how the text links dataset registration with the creation of a resource group.
Focus on who can see assets inside a resource group according to access permissions.
RG = Required Gate: resource group gates who registers and who sees the dataset.
The text states that registering a dataset assumes creation of a resource group and that the resource group is only visible to allowed users; assets are consumed within the same group.
If this were false, what would need to change about who can see datasets and when a resource group is required?
A team registers a training dataset after creating a resource group; only team members with access to that group can use it for executions.
Select all statements that are supported by the context about deploying and serving models in SAP AI Core.

After training, a model is deployed so new data can be sent to an endpoint for predictions. A Kubernetes cluster runs the serving container (CPU/GPU possible). The serving app parses the inference request body, retrieves the model from a hyperscaler object store, and the deployment exposes a URL consumable via HTTP by applications (e.g., notebooks, Postman, CAP).
An inference request is sent to an endpoint, whose web app interprets the request body before using the model.
The context states inference starts with a request to an endpoint and the web app interprets the data in the body.
The model artifact is retrieved from a hyperscaler object store as part of serving.
The text explicitly mentions retrieval from the hyperscaler object store.
Only GPU nodes can be used for serving workloads in the Kubernetes cluster.
The context notes CPU and GPU can be provided; it does not restrict serving to GPU only.
Once deployed, the model can only be consumed by SAP-specific SDKs, not generic HTTP clients.
The context says the API can be integrated using HTTP tools like Jupyter notebooks, Postman, or CAP.
Model deployment is optional in SAP AI Core because training endpoints handle real-time predictions directly.
The text differentiates training from deployment and describes deployment as enabling serving via an endpoint.
Look for statements that reflect the sequence: request to endpoint → interpret body → retrieve model → serve.
Eliminate claims that restrict consumption or infrastructure beyond what the text states.
PIPE: Parse request, Import model (from store), Predict, Expose via HTTP.
A and B mirror the described serving flow and storage. C is too restrictive about hardware. D contradicts the HTTP integration examples. E confuses training with deployment for inference.
Map each correct statement to the exact sentence in the context that supports it.
Example: A business app sends JSON to the deployment URL; the service reads the payload, fetches the model from the object store, and returns a prediction.
In SAP AI Core, which action marks the final step of the ML workflow once the model server is running and a deployment URL is available?

After training, a model is deployed so new data can be sent to an endpoint for predictions. An inference request hits an endpoint; the serving app interprets the request, retrieves the model from an object store, and runs the model server as a container on Kubernetes. Once the deployment URL is ready, the model can be used by business applications via HTTP (e.g., Jupyter notebooks, Postman, CAP).
Consuming the model via the exposed endpoint using an HTTP request.
The text states that the final step is consumption of the model through the exposed endpoint once the deployment URL is ready.
Retraining the model with additional data to improve accuracy.
Retraining is not described as the final step; deployment and subsequent consumption are emphasized.
Configuring a GPU-only Kubernetes cluster for inference.
The text mentions CPU as cheap and containerized serving on Kubernetes, but GPU-only configuration is not the final step.
Manually copying model artifacts to each application server.
The model is retrieved from a hyperscaler object store by the serving app; manual copying is not described.
Exposing the training dataset to the endpoint for validation requests.
The endpoint is for inference on new data, not for exposing training data.
Look for what happens after the deployment URL becomes available.
Focus on how business applications interact with the model.
Deploy, then Deliver: once up, you consume via the endpoint.
The passage concludes that, after the model server runs and the deployment URL is ready, the workflow ends with consumption of the model through the exposed endpoint via HTTP.
Describe a simple HTTP call (tool-agnostic) that would consume the deployed model.
A Jupyter notebook sends an HTTP POST with input data to the deployment URL and receives a prediction response.
In SAP AI Core, which sequence best describes what enables a deployment to start so that the model can be consumed via the deployment URL?

After training, a model must be deployed to serve predictions. An inference request is sent to an endpoint; the serving web application interprets the request body, retrieves the model from the hyperscaler object store, and runs the model server in a container on a Kubernetes cluster that can provide CPU resources. Once the model server is running, the deployment URL can be used by clients such as notebooks or applications.
Prompt (excerpt): “the very final step of the ML workflow in SAP AI Core is the consumption of the model through the exposed endpoint.”
Selecting the proper serving executable together with a reference to the stored model so SAP AI Core can start the model server.
The text states that combining the proper serving executable with the model reference enables SAP AI Core to start the deployment.
Issuing inference requests before the model server is running to auto-initialize the deployment URL.
